Award.AbstractNarration:
Seeds provide the majority of protein and calories in the diets of humans and livestock and are the primary means of propagation of field crops. Ovules are the developmental precursors to seeds and knowledge of the control of their development can enable modification of seed structure to alter stability, germination, nutrition, and processability, and to eliminate undesirable seeds from some fruits. While some genes controlling ovule development have been identified, there are significant gaps in our knowledge of the genetic regulation of this essential process. The awardees will utilize mutagenesis, genetics and emerging high-throughput sequencing and analysis methods to identify novel genes regulating ovule development through screening for modifiers of existing mutants. Once novel genes are identified, genetic interactions with known ovule developmental regulators will provide initial information on how the genes act during morphogenesis. Further analysis will include evaluation of protein interactions, determination of expression patterns and, if indicated, protein activity assays. The researchers will use these results to formulate a more complete picture of molecular regulation of ovule development and of mechanisms regulating morphogenesis in general.

The project spans the areas of genetics, molecular biology, developmental biology and agriculture, and leverages new concepts in sequencing and bioinformatics for rapid gene identification. The project will provide training to junior scientists and students in a research laboratory setting in genetics, plant biology and the latest methods of gene and sequence analysis. Outreach efforts will promote interest in science and scientific research among high school and middle school students at institutions with high under-represented minority enrollment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seeds are the primary sources of calories and protein in the human diet and are the main means of propagating most crop plants. Ovules are the developmental precursors of seeds and we investigate the genetic and molecular mechanisms that control their formation. In this study we used mutagenesis and genetic tools to identify new genes regulating ovule development. We showed that gated cellular ion channels are important for ovule development and for other plant developmental processes. This represents a new function for these proteins found in cellular membranes. Similarly, a new function for a protein known to regulate the degradation of other proteins was demonstrated and a novel function for a member of a class of regulators of transcription was revealed. We showed that another class of transcriptional regulator could bind to partner proteins that could either increase or decrease expression of target genes. This provided a mechanistic explanation for a prior puzzling observation that one this class of regulator had both negative and positive effects on the function of other genes. We further demonstrated how some of the genes we study are conserved in function even in plants with dramatically different ovule form. Progress was made in understanding the basis of seedless fruit formation, an important process for some fruit crops. Together our findings reveal basic processes underlying plant development and potentially facilitate the manipulation of this process for crop improvement. The research was presented to the scientific community and the public at large through five publications in peer-reviewed journals. In addition, the project provided training in the latest methods of molecular analysis of plant processes to three research professionals and five undergraduate students, facilitating their entry into positions in academic and industrial research.
